dialogues.text: over which comes appropriate musics As titles and eredits FADE, we

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: reading as follows: ’ ‘The events and characters depicted in this photoplay are not fictional, and any similarity with actual persons, either living-or dead, is ' intentional, © : . DISSOLVE TO: ~—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over these SHOTS comes the VOICE of the narrator:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: In the year 1871, a cow kicked over a lamp and started the great fire that destroyed Chicago. But, out of the ashes of that catastrophe sprang a new Chicago --

dialogues.speaker: FACTORIES
dialogues.text: Over the SHOT comes the narrator's VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- a Chicago of brick and brawn, concrete and guts; with a short history of violence beating in its ! pulse.

dialogues.speaker: , NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That history is on the record, and that record is kept by the news- papermen who have made Chicago's papers great.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS OF CHICAGO IN LATE 1952
dialogues.text: These include shots of typical scenes in that period: gangland warefare scenes, interspersed with shots of flop-houses,; men gathered outside employment agencies and men sleeping under newspapers..on park benches, and perhaps a shot of someone selling apples on a street corner + in all of them, the characteristically brutal gusts of wind for which Chicago is known. The narrator's VOICE continues:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No period in Chicago's history was more violent than the years of the depression. The rise and fall of the bootlegging empires. was written in blood and bullets. In 1932 = there were 365 murders in Chicago - one for each day of the year - eight policemen were shot down in the line of duty. One of the most cold-blooded of these murders occurred on December 9th, 1932, on South Ashland Avenue, in a place operated by a woman named Wanda Skutnike #. (NOTE: The above is broken to cover the above-mentioned SHOTS and atmospheric SHOTS of southside speakeasies. The final portion of the narration comes over a:)

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WANDA SKUTNIK'S PLACE
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE on a sign on the window which reads:

dialogues.speaker: "WANDA SKUTNIK
dialogues.text: Groceries and Delicatessen" CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see it is a bitterly colds windy day. Passersby are muffled in their overcoats and braced into the stiff wind. Traces of snow are seen swirling on doorsteps and at the curb, A wagon is stopping; the horse's head is lowered in the sharp cold wind. It is loaded with sacks of coal. On its side is lettered:

dialogues.speaker: "JAN GRUSKA
dialogues.text: COAL AND ICE” GRUSKA, a man of about forty, is dismounting.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Wanda Skutnik's store in the Polish district was the front for a speakeasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: g

dialogues.speaker: ' INT. BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: Along one side runs a makeshift bar. In o.g. empty barrels and bottles. In the center of the room is a - rough deal table, and in the back there is a pot- cellied stove with a wood and coal box beside it. At the center> table BORIS, a big, burly gorilla of a man with huge black mustachios, is finishing his drink, -WANDA SKUTNIK, the proprietress, a once attractive but now blowsy woman of about thirty-five or six, is near the stove, putting a few pieces of coal into it. _ Boris looks at her with-dog-like devotion.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (heavily) You look nice, Wanda. Wanda looks up, pleased, and walks over to the bar,

dialogues.speaker: . WANDA
dialogues.text: You say nice things, Boris,

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (softly) Nice... . Wanda grins at him. Now the door to the alley opens ; and Gruska comes in, carrying a bag of coal. He dumps the coal into the box near the potbellied stove, stamps his feet and turns to look at Wanda.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSKA
dialogues.text: It's cold out. A man could freeze. - Wanda looks at him wryly - produces a bottle and glass and brings them over to the table, ‘WANDA Help yourself. Gruska grins, sits down and starts pouring a drink, He nods at Boris, who nods back quietly and rises,

dialogues.speaker: BORLS
dialogues.text: I go now. . Wanda holds out her hand and he drops a coin into it,

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: See you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: {nodding slowly) Tonight... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 Boris. goes out the alley door, .and Wanda walks over to the icebox and takes out of it a small paper bag, in which she keeps her money. She takes a bill out of it and goes toward Gruska. Off scene we hear the SOUND of the'front door BELL. .

dialogues.speaker: WANDA -
dialogues.text: “Got change for a twenty?

dialogues.speaker: GRUSKA
dialogues.text: : (shrugs) That's all right. Pay me next. time. Wanda puts the bag back in the icebox as POLICEMAN JOHN * W. BUNDY enters. He's a big man, grey at the temples, and he's now beating his hands together to restore circulation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda, you're looking at a man with a cold coming on. ~ Bundy walks to the potbellied stove. Wanda picks up the. bottle and a glass, pours some in as she approaches Bundy, and hands him the drink as he sits down before the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a cold - this is good,

dialogues.speaker: . BUNDY
dialogues.text: Thanks. . Gruska remains seated at the table. Bundy is now fac- ing the stove, with his back to the door leading to the store. Outside, we HEAR the store door open, and the BELL ring, Wanda, who has just turned around after handing the drink to Bundy, is facing the glass parti- tion in the door that leads to the store.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT OF THE STORE
dialogues.text: We can see two huge forms of two men outlined against the daylighted windows of the. store. They are big and menacing; but we cannot see their faces or distinguish anything. about them.
Wanda looks apprehensive and puzzled, and slowly puts the bottle of liquor down on a@ table,

dialogues.speaker: BUNDY
dialogues.text: The swinging door is thrust open, and we see the lower half of the two men - and now their guns are visible. Wanda still does not see them distinctly; but she gasps. in fear when she sees the guns. She quickly dashes into the closet. One of the men starts toward the ice- box to get the money.. Then, together, both men are aware of the blue-coated figure of Bundy, just as he turns around. Gruska flings himself aside, and hides behind a'table for protection. Bundy reaches for his gun just as the two men start shooting. Bundy is hit, but lunges for. one of the men and grapples with. him, Suddenly another couple of shots are fired and Bundy staggers backward. As he falls, we HEAR rather than see the two men rushing off, because the door to the front store swings closed as Bundy crashes to the floor -- and we can HEAR the footsteps of the two men, the door BELL, and the SLAM of the front door,

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WANDA'S PLACE
dialogues.text: The two men come walking rapidly out of the store to their car. They do not have their guns in their handsy Their faces are averted as WILLIAM DECKER, a mailman, approaches. He looks curiously after them. ‘Then a gun drops from under the coat of one of the men, right at Decker's feet. The man stoops quickly and scoops it up. Decker looks at him, stunned. Then the man gets into the car and it drives off. Decker turns quickly into Wanda!s place.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WANDA'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Gruska bends over Bundy and slowly the closest door opens and Wanda peers out. “WANDA (frightened) Did they go? Just then Decker, the mailman, opens the door from the front and looks in, in horror. Gruska looks up sudden- ly. .

dialogues.speaker: GRUSKA
dialogues.text: The police! Call the police! Quick! .

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (in Polish) Bose Moj -~ t

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Another policeman murdered -- that made eight for that year! Chicago had enough - the pressure was on - find the killer! These shots are to be superimposed over running news- paper scareheads: . .

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: SCENE - Large company of policemen hurrying out of Police Station,

dialogues.speaker: B
dialogues.text: SCENE - Ext. row of cafes. Large crowd gathered looking into cafe, and scatter as cops come out with a fighting man.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: SCENE - Lineup.

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: SCENE = Police arresting customers. Crowd watching as men are dragged to the wagon. “®) HEADLINE - ROAD BLOCKS PAY OFF - BRIDGE - NIGHT SCENE - Night road block. Police at open back end of car, questioning a suspect. As the headline fades out, the narrator's VOICE con- tinues over the questioning scene:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICH
dialogues.text: This cornered, frightened bootlegger gave the tip that pointed suspicion towards a man named Tomek Zaleska...

dialogues.speaker: THE WIECEK HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is on a corner. Suddenly we can see police cars piling into the two streets from all directions. Ten or twenty men surround the house. It is a dismal little wooden frame house with perhaps four families living in it. It seems pitifully small to be attacked by such great numbers, but the policemen, some armed with sub-machine guns, others with side arms, deploy behind doorways and approach cautiously, as if they are in the process of arresting a dangerous criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Zanuck) 177

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S. VOICE
dialogues.text: Tomek Zaleska couldn't be found, but two weeks later, a’ tip from another source revealed that Tomek. hdd spent the night of the murder with his friend, Frank Wiecek. The police ' ) closed in on the home of Helen and Frank Wiecek.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WIECEK HOUSE
dialogues.text: Frank and Helen are led out, guarded by a cordon of police. Over the shot comes the VOICE of the narrator:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Helen and: Frank Wiecek were taken into custody for questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officers surround Frank, firing questions at him. He answers some. SHOT through a door or window so we don't hear them. CAMERA MOVING IN.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Frank Wieeek admitted that Tomek had spent the night of the murder at his home - but insisted he knew nothing of the crime.

dialogues.speaker: INT. QUESTIONING ROOM
dialogues.text: The officers are questioning Frank. ist CoP Why did Tomek want to Sleep -at your house?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He said he was having trouble _ with his old man, and was afraid to go home. Another cop looks at. an official card in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND COP
dialogues.text: When did you last check with the probation officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last Friday. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 2ND COP
dialogues.text: (glancing at card) You sure it wasn't Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. I know it was Friday because that was the.day my wife told me she was going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND COP
dialogues.text: : You went to the probation officer . ‘on Thursday, not Friday. (shows him card) Here's your card. Frenk stares at the card in bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST COP
dialogues.text: You're confused, son. Try to be & little more accurate. Now, what were you doing at 3:30 on December 9th? ~ .

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I was home, with my wife. I remember I was helping her shell walnuts for a cake she was making.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST COP
dialogues.text: You were wrong about the day you saw the probation officer, Maybe you're wrong about being home shelling walnuts for your wife on December 9tht

dialogues.speaker: -- FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, I made a mistake about the probation officer. But I lkmow I'm right about the other thing. The cop takes a typewritten statement from another

dialogues.speaker: 1ST COP
dialogues.text: This statement was signed by your wife an hour ago. (reads) : "My husband was home with me on the 9th of December. I remember this . because he was helping me pit dates for a cake." (putting down paper) You sure it was walnuts? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cont. 1)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (dazed) ae I = I dontt know... I'm sure she must be mistaken...

dialogues.speaker: INT, POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: Heleri is released: She exits alone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: His wife, Helen, was released.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JAIL
dialogues.text: as Frank is placed in a cell.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But because of Frank's confused testimony on insignificant. points, and his minor police record, he was held as a suspect.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CRIMINAL COURTS BLDG.
dialogues.text: A car drives up and a man gets out and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: . NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Eventually, Tomek Zaleska, protesting his innocence, surrendered to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officers are grilling Tomek the way they did Franks It's been going on for some time,

dialogues.speaker: AST COP
dialogues.text: You knew we were looking for youy You knew we picked up your good friends, Helen and Frank Wiecek}t Then why didn't you give-yourself up - if you were Innocent, as you claim? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 177 23 (Cont..) 10. TOMEK. Iv-.I was scared. Sometimes, I used to hang around Wandaty place - and when I heard they were picking ‘ up everybody she knew ~ well - I figured nobody would miss me, and IT. Just beat ite... (then) ~ -,I know now I made a mistake. (pleadingly) ~ But I came in on my own hook, didn't I? 2ND COP . When: you went to Wiecek's house that night ~ what reason did you . give for wanting to sleep there? .

dialogues.speaker: TOMEK
dialogues.text: I dontt think I gave any reason. I used to spend the night there. once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND COP
dialogues.text: (looking at paper in hand) You didn't give them any reason?

dialogues.speaker: TOMEK
dialogues.text: No, I just asked them to let me stay there, and they did.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND COP
dialogues.text: And you're sure you gave them no reason? ‘ TOMEK No. The second cop looks at the first cop skeptically and shows him the paper as we

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Wiecek' and Zaleska on trial. Wanda Skutnik is on the witness stand. Narrator'ts VOICE comes over: NARRATOR'S VOICE. Frank Wiecek and Tomek Zaleska were indicted.and swiftly brought to trial.

dialogues.speaker: MED. -SHOT
dialogues.text: The prosecutor is questioning Wanda Skutnik.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: I will ask you, Mrs. Skutnik, if you see in this courtroom the two men who murdered Policeman John Bundy? Wanda, nervous, apprehensive, lifts her eyes and stares ' offscene.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (pointing) Yes. Him, and him,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prosecutor turns to the defendants' table where Srank and Tomek sit with their attorneys, who are none too impressive in appearance. .

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Had you ever seen either of these men prior to the time of the shooting?

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Sure. Tomek used to come around my place all the time. The other fellow I never saw before.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Then the first time you saw Frank Wiecek was the night of the murder?

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Yese

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: And the next time you saw him was when you picked him out of the police line-up? Wiecek reacts, shaking his head desperately.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: That's all, Your Honor. The people reste
“INSERT - PRISON PHOTOS of Frank and Tomek, front and profile, with their num- bers prominently displayed. OVER SHOT comes the nar- rators VOICE: . .

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Frank Wiecek and Tomek Zaleska received a. sentence of 99 years in Stateville Penitentiary. This was in November of 1933. Frank and Tomek went to prison. The case was forgotten for eleven years, -- forgotten until October 10, 1944, when a small advertisement appeared in the classified advertising section of the Chicago Times -- - -prggonve to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a classified ad page of the CHICAGO TIMES dated October 10, 1944. We see the name of the. paper and the date prominently. We move down to:

dialogues.speaker: "PERSONAL NOTICES
dialogues.text: $5,000 reward for killers of Officer Bundy, on December 9, 1932. Call Northside 777, 12-7 P.M. Ask for Tillie Wiecek." A man's ‘hand COMES INTO SCENE and draws a thick blue pencil circle around it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TIMES NEWS ROOM
dialogues.text: BRIAN KELLY, the city editor, is just putting down the item. He is a quiet, chunky, very wise, soft-spoken man of about 40. One of the characteristics about him is that he smokes a brand of cigarettes with a hard cardboard tip. He doesn't use an ash tray but absently pulls the cigarette out of his mouth by clamping five fingers right around it and then stands it up on his deck, so that little clusters of half-burned cigarettes are always sticking up like tiny monuments on his desk. In the b.g. we can see the other reporters busy at their desks and copy-boys walking around. Still frowning at the item,. Kelly reaches for a cigarette, studies the item again.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: “Boy eaees, A copy-boy, who was just going by, turns toward him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: g
29 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: - Get me the file on John W, Bundy. A cop killed in 1932. The boy starts off. ‘ KELLY (calling after him) . And. get McNeal. The boy goes on his way. CAMERA FOLLOWS him to McNeal's desk. MCNEAL is an earnest, lanky man who, at the mo- ment, is busy typing out a story. .The boy walks by and taps him on ‘the shoulder but McNeal goes right on writ- ing.» -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly wants you. . a McNeal nods and the boy goes off to the file room. McNeal is just finishing his story. He starts rising, still hitting the keys as he's standing up, looking down at the’ paper. ‘Then he stops, one hand reaches out for two pages of copy lying on his desk and while he “ gtill reads the sheet in the typewriter, he taps one more letter, He starts moving, walks around the edge - of the desk and pulls the last sheet out of the type- writer as he goes by. vat McNeal puts the three sheets in order and as he reached Kelly's desk, he spikes the story on a spindle. Kelly throws some copy into a basket, picks up the clipping and hands it to McNeal.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Check this. McNeal nods without answering. He glances at the clip- ping a moment, studying it. Kelly goes right on with his. work, reading copy that has been handed to him,

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: What do you make of it?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I want to know why it's worth $5,000 to somebody to find out who killed a : _cop eleven years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: (grimly) . In 1932, it was open season on cops. On the Northside they were shooting fem in pairs, like a brace of ducks. (CONTINUED )
29 (Cont.. 1) oC) : Just then the copy-boy comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: _ (handing Kelly two- or. three clippings) This is all I could find on that cop killed in 1932 - that Bundy guy - Mr. Kelly. c | : MCNEAL. . , (to Kelly, drily) See what I mean? He didn't rate much. KELLY . Well, it won't hurt to check it, (sarcastically) . Maybe you'll get your name in the papers.- Kelly takes the cigarette out of his mouth and stands it up on the end of his desk, like ail the other. burned out stubs. McNeal looks thoughtfully at the item again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: , This is sucker-bait. Every grifter So and mooch in town will. be out after CO . that five grand. They'll frame their ‘ - brothers to get it. : (thoughtfully) Maybe this is a frame. It has a lot of angles. Kelly looks up at him with a sudden grin.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: See. what I mean? It just takes you longer to catch on.- to McNeal concedes the. point reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Well, Iwas just thinking about it. McNeal starts away. Kelly goes back to his work. CAMERA MOVES ALONG with McNeal, back to. his desk. He sits down and picks up the phone. CAMERA MOVES IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Give me Northside 777. Yeah.... right. wat ‘ (CONTINUED)
29 (Cont. 2) CO With his free hand, McNeal holds up the circled item . and looks at it thoughtfully, wonderingly.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: {continuings into phone Hello? ... Is this Northside 7779 I want to talk to Tillie Wiecek.... Yeaheses -(a pause) : . . Where can I find her...?. Yeah, I - know it's after seven, thought you might know...ee mo (repeating an address) . Where? 179....right.....thank you. He hangs up, and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘The street is deserted and there are only one or two office windows lit. .We

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: \7 We are SHOOTING the entire length of a long, long marble corridor in an office building. Far down the ‘corridor, we can discern a lonely, solitary figure, that of an old woman, down on her hands and knees, scrubbing the floor with a sponge and soap, from a bucket of water which she continually pushes in front of her. OVER SHOT we HEAR the slow methodic footsteps of one man (hard heels on his shoes) echoing hollowly through the corridors. The footsteps advance toward the.old woman. The woman is TILLIE WIECEK. MCNEALtS VOICE I'm looking for Tillie Wiecek.

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (noncommittally) What you want? CAMERA PULLS BACK. McNeal shows her the ad.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: I called Northside 777, and they. said I'd find her here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CC
dialogues.text: h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 (Cont.)

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: I'm Tillie.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Did you run this ad?_
She wipes her hands on her apron and somewhat apolo- getically takes the clipping, looks at it and nods,

dialogues.speaker: . TILLIE
dialogues.text: That's from me. (anxiously) You know something?

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL.
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No....i'm a reporter from the Chicago Tim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then) We'd like to know why you are so in- terested in finding the killers of this cop? .

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (getting up) . Frank Wiecek....is my son. I, his mother, My son is in prison for killing him, He didn't do it..,My friends tell me if I offer big money, maybe somebody will tell who kill. this policeman, The expression on McNeal's face changes, He's to get the general idea. He's got a story.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: You mean your son is in prison for killing the cop? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Yes, but he don't do it. My Frank is a good boy,...-he don't do this thing,

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Lo . (pointedly) About this five thousand dollars..., Where did you get it? beginning McNeal's attitude has crushed Tillie's hopes, and her expression changes, (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) That is important? oe MCNEAL / Yes, it's very important. Where he got it--or where you got it--might have. a lot to-do with the case. He .might have had it hidden away or maybe you. got it from some mob that's trying to spring him.

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: Notl...ee.No, it's mine! J] work.,..I scrub floors! Eleven years I save every penny. I never miss a day's work. I earn it -- every penny!

dialogues.speaker: . MCNEAL
dialogues.text: (appalled) Eleven years. That's a long time.

dialogues.speaker: ' TILLIE
dialogues.text: (majestically) : You just say it. My boy he live it, | You believe me, mister, You don't know Frank. But me, I'm his mother, I knowee.e

dialogues.speaker: . MCNEAL
dialogues.text: You. mean you've got some new evidence? Something that wasn't brought out at the trial? ~

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE,
dialogues.text: No. That's why I try to buy new evidence, , . '

dialogues.speaker: , MCNBAL .
dialogues.text: (gently) . 4 You're going to be wasting your money. ) You'll be cheated out of it.

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: No, not me.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Look, lady -- he's in for 99 years. If you want to make good use of that money, send him cigarettes and candy “and try to keep him happy.
31 (Cont. 2) OC Tillie sees that he is about to go and she puts a re- ee” straining hand on his arm,

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: You very kind, but I not use my money for candy or cigarettes... If you not able to help, I get Frank out someday, somehow. (a pause) I dream of this day.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: (cynically) Five thousand dollars is a lot for a dream.

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, eleven year I dream and I work. © First I try three thousand dollar... (hopelessly) Nothing... Now I try five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: (softly) And suppose nothing happens? . : ™ Tillie seems to draw up and grow larger and more magni- wa ficent. ° TILLIE (grimly) . Then I work eleven more years. I get ten thousand dollars, but my boy someday he get out, McNeal looks. at her admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: I've got to hand it to you, Mrs. Wiecek. You've got real courage;

dialogues.speaker: TILLIE
dialogues.text: (her eyes lighting up) You help me?

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Well, I'm afraid I can't do that. (Tillie's face falls t in disappointment) I'm just a reporter. I just write the story.ese But...egood luck to YOUesese é He turns and starts slowly away.  177 32 33 34 35 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she turns her head and looks after him. Again we HEAR the sharp, clear sound.of his footsteps, but this time receding down the corridor like the sound of hope, leaving her forever. Finally they stop. Tillie sighs, and drops to her knees, resuming her scrubbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: We are close on the Keeler polygraph -- the lie detector. “ We can see three dials, seven knobs, and three pen points, set out on the graph paper. It is a formidable looking machine, And as CAMERA slowly starts to PULL BACK from it, we can HEAR Keeler's voice coming OVER SCENE.

dialogues.text: McNeal is studying the graph. From the expression on his face, we can tell he's a little bit upset by what happened. Frank starts to walk out of the room nowe He Looks crushed and. rather frightened.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: I'll see you later, Franks Frank just ‘nods and walks out into the corridor where a trusty is waiting for him. As soon as the door is , closed behind him, McNeal turns to Keeler and points. t the graph. oo MCNEAL . What's this big jump. right here?

dialogues.speaker: " KEELER
dialogues.text: That big: jump indicates that he was lying. Kelly and Keeler come over and look at it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Was that when you asked him if he killed Bundy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No. When I asked him if he was married -= he answered 'no.' He was lying.

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: (puzzled) But he wasn't lying. He isn't married. Hets divorced.

dialogues.speaker: . KEELER
dialogues.text: (smiling a. bit) Hets a Catholic. He still feels he's married -- so his reaction was the same as if he'd told a lie.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Do you think he lied -- about any- thing else? (CONTINUED )

She looks over at McNeal, worried and then gets out of bed. She leans over him, solicitously, anxiously, and then gently shakes him, trying to rouse him from his nightmare... He wakens sluggishly.

He isn*t aware of what. hé's doing, but he starts working on it.. Then he becomes aware of the fact that Laura has suddenly appeared in the: bedroom doorway and is looking at him anxiously. He turns his head and -looks at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WACKER DRIVE
dialogues.text: As McNéal comes down the stairs leading to Michigan Boulevard, we can see the skyline behind him. He goes on into. the darkness of Wacker Drive. :

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WACKER DRIVE
dialogues.text: As McNeal comes up to the entrance, over which we see a neon sign reading: Ye Olde Cellar.

dialogues.speaker: INT. YE_OLDE CELLAR
dialogues.text: A few men are at the bar drinking beer. It 1s between mealtimes and there are no diners, except SULLIVAN. him- self, a wizened, affable little Irishman, who has a mountainous meal piled up before him on a plate and a glass of beer at his elbow. Across from him sits McNeal. SULLIVAN ‘ Mr. McNeal, there wasn't a finer man ever lived than Judge Moulton. And who would know that better than me- self?, I was his bailiff for 15 years.’ My hand to the Saints, there wasn't a finer man 6veresees

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: What I really want to know is -- did Judge Moulton promise Frank Wiecek a new trial? -

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: A new trial? Sure, and he did. . Ain't that what I've been saying all ‘ along? .

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: Are you positive of that? Sullivan peers at him darkly.

dialogues.speaker: , SULLIVAN ,
dialogues.text: . It wouldn't ‘be you're doubting my word? :

dialogues.speaker: MCNEAL
dialogues.text: All I want, Mr. Sullivan, are the details. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: (drinking beer) Ah, yes. As. I was saying. Right after the trial it was, and His Honor had - what's their names - ah, yes, Frank Wiecek and Tomek Zaleska, and the others, into his chambers -- with me there, of course, to see that no violence wag done to his person --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘CAMERA PULLS BACK from Sullivan.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You can't tell what a criminal will do next. Behind his desk sits JUDGE CHARLES MOULTON, a man of about fifty-five, still in his Judge's robes. Sullivan stands unobtrusively in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: (drily) , “tim sure you'll take good care of me, Sullivan, A guard brings Frank Wiecek and Tomek Zaleska into the room. Judge Moulton looks at them unemotionally.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: I've just passed sentence on you. 99 years. Now, Ifd like to. talk to -you -- not as your Judge, but as man to man. (a pause) The law of the State of Illinois is that a positive identification by ene eye-witness is sufficient evidence to warrant conviction of a crime. . And the jury believed Wanda Skutnik's eye-witness identification. - (to Tomek) Tell me the truth. Did you and Wiecek kill Officer Bundy? Tomek glares at the Judge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOMEK
dialogues.text: You threw the book at us, didn't you? What good would it do me to say any- thing? His voice rises emotionally and Sullivan moves forward, but Moulton stops Him with a gesture,

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: And you, Wiecek?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say? If I say yes, sure, I killed the cop -- what more can you do to me?

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: If you say no - I might be able to do something for you. But if you say no, I want it to be in the name of God. Frank stares at the Judge, a little puzzled. He comes

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I am no more guilty of killing that cop than you are. . “MOULTON And that is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I swore, didn't I? On the Bible. I'm a Catholic, Your Honor, and I --

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: All right, Frank. (ne rises and smiles) I just want to tell you boys - I think you got a rotten deal. around the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: I was astonished at the verdict -- but I had to sentence you. The jury gave me no alternative. But though I have no authority to demand a new trial for you -- I'll see that you get it somehow, (CONTINUED)
oy - (moved) ; Sd : Thank -- thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TOMEK
dialogues.text: -- Ana -- I'm sorry, sir. I guess I lost my head. a MOWLTON You. had a right to. He shakes hands with each of them in turn.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: (to guard) Bring in Decker, Gruska, and the | Skutnik woman. : The guard leads Frank and Tomek out. Moulton sighs, and. turns to Sullivan. .

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: I'd give anything if I could have heard this case. without a jury.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: ‘ (affectionately) Co Sure, Your Honor has more sense than any twelve men - especially when some of them are women. Moulton smiles a little at this, and sits down. The . guard brings Decker, Gruska, and Wanda Skutnik into the room, They line up before the desk, Decker and Gruska puzzled and embarrassed; Wanda openly defiant. The judge looks at them keenly, letting them sweat it out for a long moment before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: _ MOULTON
dialogues.text: (finally) Mr. Decker -- you swore, under oath, that you could not identify either Frank Wiecek or Tomek Zaleska as the murderers.

dialogues.speaker: DECKER
dialogues.text: That's. right, sir. Like I testified, they had their coat collars turned-up, and their faces were hidden -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: But you saw their approximate height, and weight. And you've seen both Wiecek and Zaleska? Would you say they could -- bear in mind I said could -- could have been the same men?- Decker shakes his head apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: DECKER
dialogues.text: No, sir. I don't think they could.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: Mr. Gruska, you were in the room when the murder was committed. What do you have to say? . .

dialogues.speaker: GRUSKA
dialogues.text: (nervous, afraid) I swear to that, like I testify - they big men - Wiecek and Zaleska, they not so big = not so. big like the men. who shoot policeman - I know = . ' Moulton nods and turns to Wanda Skutnik.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: And yet you, Mrs. Skutnik -- you alone, of all the witnesses, have testified under oath that you posi- tively recognized both defendants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . (without emotion) I did -- and it's true. I gota better look at them. : Moulton looks at her suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSKA
dialogues.text: Judge.o..she's a liar. She ran into the closet. I hid behind the stove. The shots were fired. They fought...- and all the time I saw. But all the - time, she was in the closet. She could not see nothing. Skutnik's face freezes and she clams up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gruska) Why didn't you say that at the trial? GRUSKA . The lawyers didn't ask me. They warn me to just answer question, yes. or no,

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: (nodding) I think that'll be all. You may go. The guard ushers them out. Wanda avoids looking at the Judge. Moulton rises again, walks around the desk and paces, thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: MOULTON
dialogues.text: , She's lying,, Sullivan. Lying. And that jury believed her....

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: The Judge was a wonderful man.. He did intend to get the boys a new trial -- you have my word. (he sighs) Then shortly after, he died...rest his soul...before he could do any- thing about it. Some of the cynicism is gone from McNeal's face. He is drawing aimless patterns on the tablecloth with a fork.

dialogues.speaker: . MCNEAL
dialogues.text: _ If we only had some way to prove it. Were you the only one in the room beside Frank and Tomek when the Judge promised them a new trial? .

dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) That I weasese McNeal looks disappointed,.. (CONTINUED)
